title: Enhancing Non-Core Language Instruction-Following in Speech LLMs via Semi-Implicit Cross-Lingual CoT Reasoning
author: Hongfei Xue (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Jun Zhang (ByteDance Inc.), Yufeng Tang (ByteDance Inc.), Xuelong Geng (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Hexin Liu (Nanyang Technological University), Lei Xie (Northwestern Polytechnical University)
relevance_why: This paper introduces a novel framework (XS-CoT) that could significantly enhance performance for non-core language processing in speech recognition tasks, which aligns closely with the focus on audio and language processing in Haohe Liu's work.
background: The development of large language models for speech applications often shows lower performance in non-core languages due to limited data availability.
contribution: This paper introduces the XS-CoT framework to improve instruction-following performance in speech LLMs for non-core languages, achieving up to 45% better responses compared to direct supervised fine-tuning.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing frameworks generally struggle with low-resource languages and often rely heavily on explicit reasoning via intermediate tokens, leading to latency issues.
technical_comparison.novelty: XS-CoT incorporates a semi-implicit reasoning scheme, reducing inference delays while retaining effective reasoning by compressing less critical intermediate details.

key_innovation: The framework generates multiple types of tokens sequentially, leveraging core language reasoning to improve responses in non-core languages.
real_world_impact: If successfully implemented, this approach could make speech technologies more accessible across different languages, improving user interactions in multilingual contexts.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention any limitations but implies challenges related to maintaining model performance across diverse languages.

new_terms.XS-CoT: **Cross-lingual Speech Chain-of-Thought** is a framework combining speech-to-text translation and iterative reasoning strategies for improved multilingual instruction-following in speech models.

open_sourcing: Datasets in Japanese, German, and French have been open-sourced to support the XS-CoT training process.
